page.text: Appendix I – Rate of Return Analysis
The purpose of this Safety Study is to identify crash problems, determine site-specific
countermeasures, and set up reasonable time periods to implement the proposed
countermeasures at the intersection of Brookpark Road (SR-17) and State Road (SR 94). More
specifically, this report is setup to address the recent crash history (46 crashes between 2008
and 2010) and provide recommendations to items associated with the crash history such as
The Ohio Department of Transportation (ODOT) utilizes SafetyAnalyst which is a highway safety
management software program developed in conjunction with the Highway Safety Manual
through the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) to
flag and rank intersections and segments that have higher than predicted crash frequencies.
The most recent three years of available crash data (2008 – 2010) were used to compile the
SafetyAnalyst rankings and will be used for this report.
The intersection of Brookpark Road and State Road ranked #35 statewide on the 2010 ODOT
SafetyAnalyst Fatal and Serious Injury, Non-Freeway list for “higher than predicted crash
frequency involving fatal or serious injuries.”
Brookpark Road and State Road are both classified as minor urban arterials. All approaches
contain exclusive left turn lanes while the southbound approach on State Road also contains an
exclusive right turn lane. The posted speed limit on Brookpark Road is 35 MPH. On State Road,
the posted speed limit is 35 MPH just north of Brookpark Road and 25 MPH just south of
Based on crash data obtained from ODOT, the most common types of crashes in the study area
are left turn and rear end crashes. The majority of left turn crashes are occurring within the
intersection in the eastbound and westbound directions along Brookpark Road. Rear end
crashes are also occurring primarily in the eastbound and westbound directions.
Both types of crashes can be attributed to congestion and driver frustration/impatience caused
by poor level of service and long delays. Observations revealed no visible vehicle detection and
an apparent pretimed signal operation. The lack a vehicle actuation is contributing to an
The proposed improvement phases for this study can be categorized into short-term and
medium-term phases. General countermeasures are also listed. These recommendations are
proven countermeasures that can be applied to the study intersection. See section 8.0
upgrading all pedestrian signals to countdown LED signals with pushbuttons for
upgrading signs with highly reflective sheeting (short term),
upgrading the traffic controller to add left turn lane stop bar detection,
adding lane control signs for the northbound approach,
adding two signal heads for the southbound approach,
studying the feasibility of coordinating traffic signals along State Road from
Burger Avenue, north of I-480, to Brookpark Road.
DLZ estimated construction costs for year 2012 and included a 20% contingency. For the short-
term improvements, the estimated cost is $79,800.

movements for the drives at the northwest and southwest corners,
reconfiguring the intersection to provide southbound dual left turn lanes and
upgrading the entire intersection with additional signal heads, new mast arms,
adding an exclusive right turn lane to Brookpark Road for the westbound
For medium-term improvements, the estimated construction cost is $485,100 with a 35% rate
of return. This includes a 35% contingency. Right of way costs are included in this estimate as
are public utility relocation (notably waterwork which includes relocating hydrants). Private
utility relocation is not included but several utility poles along the north side of Brookpark Road
present an obstacle to widening for a westbound exclusive right lane.
The study intersection is located in the cities of Cleveland and Parma within Cuyahoga County,
Ohio. The City of Cleveland maintains and operates the traffic signal installation. The four-
legged intersection consists of Brookpark Road, which runs east and west, and State Road,
which runs north and south. Both roadways are classified as minor urban arterials. All
lanes while the southbound approach on
State Road also contains an exclusive
Traffic is controlled by a pretimed, box

section signal heads with arrows are
turns on each approach. Sidewalks, curb
are present at each quadrant of this
are present only on the southern corners.
There are no pedestrian pushbuttons or visible vehicle detection present. On-street parking is
prohibited on all approaches within the intersection area.
Several signals lie within close proximity to the subject intersection. In particular, an
interchange with I-480 is located approximately 800 feet north of the study intersection. The
study intersection runs isolated and is not coordinated with the I-480 signals. See the Traffic
Signal Proximity map on the next page for locations and distances.
The area is heavily commercial along both Brookpark Road and State Road with residential
neighborhoods branching from State Road south of the intersection.
Pavement and pavement markings are in fair condition throughout the study area at the time
of this report. The northbound, eastbound, and westbound approaches are asphalt while the
southbound leg is concrete. All approaches are curbed.
The posted speed limit on Brookpark Road is 35 MPH. On State Road, the posted speed limit is
35 MPH just north of Brookpark Road and 25 MPH just south of Brookpark Road. Street lighting
is present along both roadways. See Appendix A for the condition diagram.
DLZ received crash data from ODOT in the form of the Crash Analysis Module (CAM) Tool. Data
was verified by location and type utilizing OH-1 reports provided. The most recent three years
of data available (2008 – 2010) was analyzed for crash trends and safety issues. Table 1
All crashes provided by ODOT in the CAM Tool were within the study area. Furthermore, all
crashes were properly logged except for one location which was mislogged as occurring on
Brookpark Road approaching State Road when actually the crash occurred on Brookpark Road
approach I-480. Seven crashes were changed from angle crash to left turn crash based on the
Based on crash data obtained from ODOT, the most common type of crash is the left turn crash.
Between 2008 and 2010, 18 left turn crashes occurred at the study intersection (about 40% of
all crashes), 6 of which caused an injury. Fourteen left turn crashes occurred within the
intersection while four occurred at driveway locations. Within the intersection, four left turn
crashes occurred for each westbound and eastbound vehicle movement.
The second most frequently occurring crash from 2008 to 2010 at this intersection was the rear
end crash. Sixteen rear end crashes accounted for about 35% of all crashes. Rear ends were
Crash rate = 0.88 crashes per million entering vehicles
mainly intersection related and largely occurred when vehicles slowed down and stopped on an
approach due to a red light or when a driver stopped to allow access into or out of a drive.
Seven rear end crashes occurred on the westbound approach and five on the eastbound
No recorded crashes involved a pedestrian or bicyclist. No fatal crashes were recorded.
For a detailed breakdown of all crashes, see the crash summary in Appendix B and the collision
DLZ observed the intersection on several occasions between February and April of 2012.
Observations were made for AM, midday, and PM peak hours. DLZ also conducted turning
movement counts on Wednesday, March 21, 2012. A breakdown of the traffic volumes is listed
PM peak traffic contained the largest vehicle volumes. The most notable heavy vehicle
movements (trucks + buses) were southbound left turns from State Road to Brookpark Road
and westbound right turns from Brookpark Road to State Road. The largest observed queues
were southbound and largely stemmed from both eastbound and westbound I-480 exit ramps.
In length, southbound queues extended up to 1,000 feet during observations.
75% of all crashes were intersection related,
25% of all crashes were driveway related,
33% of all crashes occurred between 3 and 6 PM,
3 crashes involved an alcohol impaired driver,
Adverse weather and nighttime crashes were not significant.
AM peak traffic was largely heading toward I-480 as the heaviest movement was the
The ADT derived from DLZ’s eight hour count is comparable to recent ODOT data. The Traffic
Survey Report from 2010 lists the ADT along Brookpark Road as approximately 22,770 vehicles
per day west of the study intersection and 25,020 vehicles per day east of the study
intersection. The ADT along State Road between the study intersection and I-480 is
The signal operates in a pretimed manner under different timing plans. The left turn phases are
all fixed time, leading phases. Pedestrian timings are also fixed as there are no pedestrian
pushbuttons at this intersections. The signals just north of this intersection at the I-480 ramps
are coordinated, but this intersection is not part of any coordinated system. The City of
Cleveland maintains and operates traffic control at the study intersection. Phase timing data
and cycle length variations are listed below. Currently, the signal operates under the same
timing parameters during the AM and PM peak (150 second cycle plan).
DLZ measured existing yellow and all-red clearance intervals as well as pedestrian clearance
intervals and compared them to recommendations from the TEM Section 403-2 and OMUTCD
Section 4D.26. DLZ recommends increasing yellow time for all left turn phases from 3.0
seconds to 3.6 seconds. No changes are recommended for all red times or pedestrian clearance
Overhead lane control signs are present for eastbound, westbound, and southbound
approaches. There are no lane control signs present for the northbound approach.
There are several driveways in close proximately to the intersection. Notably, the Sunoco gas
station on the northwest corner and the BP gas station on the southwest corner both have
multiple drives on State Road and Brookpark Road.
Turning lane lengths were calculated based on the ODOT Location and Design Manual, Volume
1, Section 400. Utilizing approach speed and peak traffic volumes, the chart below is a
summary of recommended design turn lane lengths.

text.i: values are in feet, *per lane for dual LT's, **thru becomes exclusive RT

page.text: Traffic count data collected by DLZ was utilized to measure capacity using Highway Capacity
Software (HCS) to determine Level of Service (LOS) and average delay per approach. DLZ
counted the number of vehicles that travelled through the intersection and did not account for
intersection demand from queued vehicles. Turning movement counts are available in
The concept of LOS is a qualitative measure of the operation of traffic flow. LOS considers such
factors as speed, travel time, freedom to maneuver, traffic interruptions, driver inconvenience,
safety, and delay. Signalized intersections are measured for average control delay in seconds
per vehicle. Control delay includes initial deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped
delay, and final deceleration delay. The delay measurement for vehicles at a signalized
intersection is a combination of driver discomfort, driver frustration, and lost travel time.
The LOS rating system as described in the 2010 Highway Capacity Manual gives a value of A
through F to each type of roadway facility representing best to worst traffic conditions.

text.i: Table 4- LOS Criteria for Signalized Intersections

page.text: > 10 sec. but not more than 20 sec. per vehicle
> 20 sec. but not more than 35 sec. per vehicle
> 35 sec. but not more than 55 sec. per vehicle
> 55 sec. but not more than 80 sec. per vehicle
DLZ analyzed the existing signal timings along with several alternative timings using Synchro
software. Signal timings were optimized for four alternatives:
 Alternative 1 – add detection for all exclusive left turn lanes and make left turn phases
 Alternative 2 – add a westbound exclusive right turn lane on Brookpark Road
 Alternative 3 – reconfigure southbound approach of State Road for dual left turn lanes
 Alternative 4 – Full Build (add westbound exclusive right turn lane and southbound dual
For the four proposed alternatives above, DLZ changed the pedestrian control from pedestrian
recall for all pedestrian phases to actuated pedestrian calls only. This assumes the traffic
controller will be upgraded and pushbuttons will be added. This will provide signal flexibility
especially in periods with low pedestrian volumes.
Complete Synchro results for existing conditions and the four alternatives are available in
Appendix E along with queue lengths. The table on the next page shows a summary of the
capacity analysis results. For each alternative, delays were balanced among movements and
the cycle length was optimized to yield the lowest intersection delay. Average intersection
delay per vehicle decreased for each alternative relative to the existing conditions.
Signal timings were adjusted at the study intersection by the City of Cleveland in the
There is a FY2013 signal maintenance contract through District 12 (PID 88276) that may
apply to this intersection for rapid implementation of left turn vehicle detection.
District 12 also has a FY2018 urban paving project (PID 89267) that may apply to this
location to incorporate medium-term recommendations such as widening or
Based on field observations, crash data, and analysis of the intersection, there are several
improvements that can be made to potentially reduce crashes and increase safety.
Left turn crashes were the most frequently occurring crash from 2008 to 2010 within the study
limits accounting for 40% of all crashes. This type of crash primarily occurred within the
intersection in the eastbound and westbound directions on Brookpark Road. Capacity analysis
in Section 5.0 reveals that the eastbound and westbound movements on Brookpark Road have
some of the highest intersection delays during the peak hours. One potential solution is to add
left turn detection at the intersection. There is no vehicle detection visible at the intersection
and signal timings remained constant during observations for each timing plan. Adding
detection would allow the intersection to operate more efficiently specifically because
northbound left turns are light throughout the day and westbound left turns are light in the
AM, thus allowing for unused green time to be allocated to other movements.
Rear end crashes were the second most frequently occurring crash accounting for 35% of all
crashes. Again, most crashes of this type occurred in the eastbound and westbound directions
on Brookpark Road. Common causes for rear end crashes at signals are poor progression, long
delays, inefficient signal timing, queues that don’t clear and poor signal visibility. Adjacent
traffic signals on Brookpark Road are likely too far to consider coordination, however DLZ
recommends exploring the feasibility of coordinating the study intersection with the I-480 ramp
signals. The first signal north of I-480, Burger Avenue, should also be considered in this study.
DLZ explored two additional alternatives which specifically would add intersection capacity and
potentially improve safety. The first is to add a westbound exclusive right turn lane. The
westbound approach would benefit by the additional lane and furthermore the opportunity to
create a right turn overlap phase during the southbound protected left turn phase. To widen
Brookpark, there are potential right of way impacts along with utility poles, a traffic signal
support pole, and a hydrant that would need to be relocated. Also, widening would lengthen

Another countermeasure to consider is upgrading
all signals to 12-inch LED indications with black
backplates and retroreflective strips to increase
signal visibility. Although rear end crashes and
red light running are likely associated more with
driver frustration due to severe congestion than
signal visibility, backplates still have potential to
reduce rear end crashes in addition to potentially
reducing red light running. Backplates can also
help reduce sun glare and eliminate the negative effects of background clutter (which is
prevalent on all approaches). Because the current support system is span wire, consider
upgrading the entire signal installation including mast arms.
Additional signal heads may increase visibility especially on the southbound approach which
has four lanes and only two signal heads. An additional signal on this approach can be added to
the span wire (if the existing supports can handle the additional load) and as a near right signal
on the northwest corner of the intersection. The near right and the western-most signal should
include right turn arrows to allow a southbound protected right turn phase during the

close proximity of the intersection, only four
crashes were directly related to driveways.

DLZ recommends upgrading signs that are not highly reflective including the overhead lane use
signs. Also consider installing a ground mounted lane use sign for the northbound approach.
See Appendix F for a drawing of recommended improvements.

page.text: Proposed countermeasures can be categorized in three improvement phases, which are the
short-term, medium-term, and long term phases. The short-term phase improvements should
be implemented within one year. Medium-term phase improvements are intended for one to
five years. Long-term improvements are intended for over five years. There are no
recommended long-term improvements for this study. The general recommendations are
proven countermeasures that can be applied to the study intersection. They are not included in
cost estimates or rate of return analysis.
Consider upgrading all pedestrian signals to countdown LED signals with
Consider upgrading signs with highly reflective sheeting (short term),
Consider upgrading the traffic controller to add left turn lane stop bar detection,
Consider adding lane control signs for the northbound approach,
Consider adding two signal heads for the southbound approach,
Consider studying the feasibility of coordinating traffic signals along State Road
from Burger Avenue, north of I-480, to Brookpark Road.
DLZ estimated construction costs for year 2012 and included a 20% contingency. For the short-
term improvements, the estimated cost is $79,800. See Appendix H for a breakdown of costs.
Consider access management strategies such as eliminating, relocating, or
restricting movements for the drives at the northwest and southwest corners,
Consider reconfiguring the north approach to provide southbound dual left turn
lanes (approximately 625 feet in length each) and two northbound receiving
lanes as well as widening the northbound approach to provide positive
Consider upgrading the entire intersection with additional signal heads, new
mast arms, LED indications, and backplates,
Consider adding an exclusive right turn lane (approximately 600 feet in length) to
Brookpark Road for the westbound approach.
For medium-term improvements, the estimated construction cost is $485,100 with a 35% rate
of return. This includes a 35% contingency. Right of way costs are included in this estimate as
are public utility relocation (notably waterwork which includes relocating hydrants). Private
utility relocation is not included but several utility poles along the north side of Brookpark Road
present an obstacle to widening for a westbound exclusive right lane. Rate of return analysis is
